Top Ten Cocktails

22/10/2013

Get inspired by these classic cocktails, heavyweights both in fame and alcoholic content.

Image by

By undefined undefined

Dry Martini: The Godfather of cocktails. It's simple to make, crisp and elegant. It's cliche, but let's face it; it makes you feel like James Bond. The great thing about a Martini is that there is something for everyone; it's a cocktail chameleon. From an original dry to a fruit-flavoured, right to the dirty martini for those feeling particularly filthy. Dry Martini contains: 2 shots gin, 1/2 shot vermouth, 1 twist lemon. Cosmopolitan: A more recent invention, but the Cosmo has managed to work its way up to the top of those bar menus. And with good reason; it tastes delicious. Although commonly seen as a feminine drink, men need not be afraid. In the metropolitan, metrosexual society we live in, it's ok for guys to order fruity, nice-tasting drinks. If you're still having doubts, you can always tell your mates it's Koppaberg in a fancy glass. Contains: 1 shot Ketel One Citroen, 1 shot Cointreau triple sec, 1 shot cranberry juice, squeeze of lime juice, 1 (optional) dash Orange Bitters Long Island Iced Tea: Despite the name, the Long Island Iced Tea doesn't actually contain iced tea. However it's just as sweet and tasty, but packs a punch. Through some kind of mixology sorcery, the Long Island Iced Tea contains large amounts of alcohol, but still tastes damn good. You definitely get your money's worth of alcohol when order one of these at a bar. Contains: 1/2 shot each of barcardi, gin, vodka, Cointreau triple sec, tequila, sugar syrup, lime juice and lemon juice. Top up with coke. Manhattan: The Manhattan was the first cocktail to use Vermouth, making it essentially the fore-runner and mature older brother of the Martini. The Manhattan is like a dry Martini with its sharp corners sanded down. Not as sharp, but rather smooth and warming; making the Manhattan a perfect, albeit unlikely comfort drink in the depths of winter. Contains: 2 1/2 shots bourbon, 1/2 shot sweet vermouth, 1/2 shot dry vermouth, liberal dash of Angostura Bitters. Mojito: An easily accessible taste of the exotic, everyone loves a good mojito. The freshness of the mint compliments the tartness of the lime bringing a real flavour sensation. I would really recommend making your own rather than buying the pre-mixed bottles as everyone's taste is different. Making a good mojito is mainly trial and improvement, so the following is more of a guideline than a strict recipe. Contains: 2 shots Bacardi, generous splash of lime juice, brown sugar, several mint leaves. Top up with soda water. Bellini: Sophisticated, but fun, the Bellini is the Wimbledon of the cocktail world. Originally named after a saint in a painting by 15th century artist Giovanni Bellini, the drink is a lot less innocent than its namesake. Devilishly delicious, it's a dessert in its own right. Contains: 2 shots peach juice, squeeze of lemon, top up with Prosecco. Mexican Mule: The name may sound like a Latin American drug cartel, but this is actually a new and interesting twist on the traditional Moscow Mule. The introduction of tequila adds an extra kick that gives it an edge. It's a real fiesta in the mouth! It's also a good palate cleanser, so would make a perfect aperitif. Contains: 1 1/2 shots tequila, squeeze of lime, dash of sugar syrup, top up with ginger beer. Tom Collins: Very simple, very straightforward, and if made well also very delicious. The Tom Collins is another drink that finds its heritage in prohibition and certainly one of the most refreshing. This is another cocktail I would recommend making at home rather than ordering in a bar, as it tastes best when made with freshly squeezed lemon juice. The ingredients are so few and so widely available, that it's also a cheap one to make at home. Contains: 2 shots gin, squeeze lemon juice, dash of sugar syrup (or just a tsp sugar), and top up with soda. Vodka Tea: Not quite a fully-fledged cocktail, but definitely a must-try drink. Sounds disgusting, I know, but give it a chance. This is not a drink I would recommend ordering in a club, but after a messy night, it can really settle your stomach. The vodka makes the tea taste sweet, and the tea takes the bite out of the vodka. It's a partnership made in heaven. Or in your kitchen at 4am. This would place higher, but it can be pretty dangerous; one bad experience can ruin tea for you forever, so be careful! Vodka tea contains: 1 bottle vodka, 4 tea bags, and 1 cup of sugar. In a drink: 2 1/2 shots vodka tea, top up with lemonade. Whisky Sour: Classy, smart, clean. With a whisky sour what you see is what you get. As the name suggests, it's pretty sour. Although some (me included) enjoy the sharp, acidic taste, it can be a bit much. The addition of egg whites can smooth it down for those with a less hardened palate, however egg is not an ingredient I would suggest for beginners as it has to potential to turn very frothy, giving you a drink with the taste and texture of washing-up liquid. Contains: 2 shots scotch, squeeze lemon juice, 1/2 shot sugar syrup, generous dash Angostura Bitters, 1/2 an egg white (if you're feeling brave) and if you've got it, 1/2 shot aniseed liqueur.
